nodes.text: I think red eye is correct:
mcolmenter(319): I think red eye is correct:
Annot: I think red eye is correct:
DOT is on a slippery slope if it bans peanuts.
mcolmenter(319): DOT is on a slippery slope if it bans peanuts.
Annot: DOT is on a slippery slope if it bans peanuts.
However, I also understand the concerns of people with severe peanut allergies.
mcolmenter(319): However, I also understand the concerns of people with severe peanut allergies.
Annot: However, I also understand the concerns of people with severe peanut allergies.
Perhaps airlines could offer only select flights as "PeanutFree" instead of a complete ban on peanuts.
mcolmenter(319): Perhaps airlines could offer only select flights as "PeanutFree" instead of a complete ban on peanuts.
Annot: Perhaps airlines could offer only select flights as "PeanutFree" instead of a complete ban on peanuts.
I am the mom of a child with allergies to peanuts
Elle(320): I am the mom of a child with allergies to peanuts
Annot: I am the mom of a child with allergies to peanuts
(& I have an allergy to shellfish)
Elle(320): (& I have an allergy to shellfish)
Annot: (& I have an allergy to shellfish)
and have flown six times (on Delta) with my child and had no problems,
Elle(320): and have flown six times (on Delta) with my child and had no problems,
Annot: and have flown six times (on Delta) with my child and had no problems,
though some anxiety.
Elle(320): though some anxiety.
Annot: though some anxiety.
Delta's policy is to create a peanutfree buffer three rows in front & three rows behind the peanutallergic person.
Elle(320): Delta's policy is to create a peanutfree buffer three rows in front & three rows behind the peanutallergic person.
Annot: Delta's policy is to create a peanutfree buffer three rows in front & three rows behind the peanutallergic person.
One flight happened to be peanutfree because there were several passengers on the flight with peanut allergies,
Elle(320): One flight happened to be peanutfree because there were several passengers on the flight with peanut allergies,
Annot: One flight happened to be peanutfree because there were several passengers on the flight with peanut allergies,
and the buffer zones pretty much took up the entire plane.
Elle(320): and the buffer zones pretty much took up the entire plane.
Annot: and the buffer zones pretty much took up the entire plane.
The other flights were not peanutfree.
Elle(320): The other flights were not peanutfree.
Annot: The other flights were not peanutfree.
Carry all necessary medication, including at least two selfinjectors
Elle(320): Carry all necessary medication, including at least two selfinjectors
Annot: Carry all necessary medication, including at least two selfinjectors
(I get Twinjects because two injectors have four doses.)
Elle(320): (I get Twinjects because two injectors have four doses.)
Annot: (I get Twinjects because two injectors have four doses.)
Let the airline know at the time of my reservation of our allergies and that I plan to board early.
Elle(320): Let the airline know at the time of my reservation of our allergies and that I plan to board early.
Annot: Let the airline know at the time of my reservation of our allergies and that I plan to board early.
Mention this again at the gate.
Elle(320): Mention this again at the gate.
Annot: Mention this again at the gate.
Bring Clorox wipes and clean my daughter's seat, tray table etc. and the seats on either side or window/wall if she has a window seat.
Elle(320): Bring Clorox wipes and clean my daughter's seat, tray table etc. and the seats on either side or window/wall if she has a window seat.
Annot: Bring Clorox wipes and clean my daughter's seat, tray table etc. and the seats on either side or window/wall if she has a window seat.
Bring food so we don't have to rely on the airline food.
Elle(320): Bring food so we don't have to rely on the airline food.
Annot: Bring food so we don't have to rely on the airline food.
As mentioned by someone previously, banning peanuts is a slippery slope
Elle(320): As mentioned by someone previously, banning peanuts is a slippery slope
Annot: As mentioned by someone previously, banning peanuts is a slippery slope
because there are many people with lifethreatening allergies to many foods.
Elle(320): because there are many people with lifethreatening allergies to many foods.
Annot: because there are many people with lifethreatening allergies to many foods.
Shellfish allergies are more common in adults than peanuts.
Elle(320): Shellfish allergies are more common in adults than peanuts.
Annot: Shellfish allergies are more common in adults than peanuts.

Someone wrote above "As for the 'slippery slope' argument  I don't buy it. I've never heard of anyone having a wheat allergy going into anaphylaxis from someone sitting next to them eating a sandwich."

Elle(320): Someone wrote above "As for the 'slippery slope' argument  I don't buy it. I've never heard of anyone having a wheat allergy going into anaphylaxis from someone sitting next to them eating a sandwich."

Annot: Someone wrote above "As for the 'slippery slope' argument  I don't buy it. I've never heard of anyone having a wheat allergy going into anaphylaxis from someone sitting next to them eating a sandwich."
Interesting point,
Elle(320): Interesting point,
Annot: Interesting point,
but I can turn it around
Elle(320): but I can turn it around
Annot: but I can turn it around
as I have never heard of a documented case of anyone going into anaphylaxis from airborne contact of peanuts.
Elle(320): as I have never heard of a documented case of anyone going into anaphylaxis from airborne contact of peanuts.
Annot: as I have never heard of a documented case of anyone going into anaphylaxis from airborne contact of peanuts.
From what I understand, airborne anaphylaxis is very rare.
Elle(320): From what I understand, airborne anaphylaxis is very rare.
Annot: From what I understand, airborne anaphylaxis is very rare.
If anything, I would suggest a ban on warming up peanuts,
Elle(320): If anything, I would suggest a ban on warming up peanuts,
Annot: If anything, I would suggest a ban on warming up peanuts,
since that is more likely to put peanut proteins in the air.
Elle(320): since that is more likely to put peanut proteins in the air.
Annot: since that is more likely to put peanut proteins in the air.
I would also suggest training staff to be sensitive to passengers with allergies.
Elle(320): I would also suggest training staff to be sensitive to passengers with allergies.
Annot: I would also suggest training staff to be sensitive to passengers with allergies.
(most have them,
Elle(320): (most have them,
Annot: (most have them,
it's just tough to find on their sites)
Elle(320): it's just tough to find on their sites)
Annot: it's just tough to find on their sites)
and be consistent
Elle(320): and be consistent
Annot: and be consistent
so a passenger doesn't think she is flying on a nutfree flight when it isn't.
Elle(320): so a passenger doesn't think she is flying on a nutfree flight when it isn't.
Annot: so a passenger doesn't think she is flying on a nutfree flight when it isn't.
And while this forum is great,
Elle(320): And while this forum is great,
Annot: And while this forum is great,
I would weigh more the advice of researchers.
Elle(320): I would weigh more the advice of researchers.
Annot: I would weigh more the advice of researchers.
Many people react emotionally regarding this issue
Elle(320): Many people react emotionally regarding this issue
Annot: Many people react emotionally regarding this issue
and when DOT considers options, it should take into consideration what scientific studies have shown have occurred or may occur, not what wellintentioned people or panicked people think may occur.

Elle(320): and when DOT considers options, it should take into consideration what scientific studies have shown have occurred or may occur, not what wellintentioned people or panicked people think may occur.

Annot: and when DOT considers options, it should take into consideration what scientific studies have shown have occurred or may occur, not what wellintentioned people or panicked people think may occur.
Epinephrine should always be the responsibility of the passenger,
Elle(320): Epinephrine should always be the responsibility of the passenger,
Annot: Epinephrine should always be the responsibility of the passenger,
though it may be good policy to have extra on board in the event of an anaphylaxis (or severe asthma attack).
Elle(320): though it may be good policy to have extra on board in the event of an anaphylaxis (or severe asthma attack).
Annot: though it may be good policy to have extra on board in the event of an anaphylaxis (or severe asthma attack).
A passenger's bill or rights/ responsibilities would be helpful.
Elle(320): A passenger's bill or rights/ responsibilities would be helpful.
Annot: A passenger's bill or rights/ responsibilities would be helpful.

Elle(320): I am the mom of a child with allergies to peanuts (& I have an allergy to shellfish) and have flown six times (on Delta) with my child and had no problems, though some anxiety. Delta's policy is to create a peanutfree buffer three rows in front & three rows behind the peanutallergic person.  One flight happened to be peanutfree because there were several passengers on the flight with peanut allergies, and the buffer zones pretty much took up the entire plane.  The other flights were not peanutfree.What I do for flights:  Carry all necessary medication, including at least two selfinjectors (I get Twinjects because two injectors have four doses.)  Let the airline know at the time of my reservation of our allergies and that I plan to board early.   Mention this again at the gate.   Bring Clorox wipes and clean my daughter's seat, tray table etc. and the seats on either side or window/wall if she has a window seat.  Bring food so we don't have to rely on the airline food. As mentioned by someone previously, banning peanuts is a slippery slope because there are many people with lifethreatening allergies to many foods. Shellfish allergies are more common in adults than peanuts.Someone wrote above "As for the 'slippery slope' argument  I don't buy it. I've never heard of anyone having a wheat allergy going into anaphylaxis from someone sitting next to them eating a sandwich."Interesting point, but I can turn it around as I have never heard of a documented case of anyone going into anaphylaxis from airborne contact of peanuts. From what I understand, airborne anaphylaxis is very rare.If anything, I would suggest a ban on warming up peanuts, since that is more likely to put peanut proteins in the air. I would also suggest training staff to be sensitive to passengers with allergies.  They should create allergy policies and post them in an easily findable place on their websites (most have them, it's just tough to find on their sites) and be consistent so a passenger doesn't think she is flying on a nutfree flight when it isn't. And while this forum is great, I would weigh more the advice of researchers.  Many people react emotionally regarding this issue and when DOT considers options, it should take into consideration what scientific studies have shown have occurred or may occur, not what wellintentioned people or panicked people think may occur.Epinephrine should always be the responsibility of the passenger, though it may be good policy to have extra on board in the event of an anaphylaxis (or severe asthma attack). A passenger's bill or rights/ responsibilities would be helpful. (e.g. Encourage people with allergies to carry two or more selfinjectors; Giving people with food allergies  Anyone with a medical condition actually  the option to board the plane early.

Annot: I am the mom of a child with allergies to peanuts (& I have an allergy to shellfish) and have flown six times (on Delta) with my child and had no problems, though some anxiety. Delta's policy is to create a peanutfree buffer three rows in front & three rows behind the peanutallergic person.  One flight happened to be peanutfree because there were several passengers on the flight with peanut allergies, and the buffer zones pretty much took up the entire plane.  The other flights were not peanutfree.What I do for flights:  Carry all necessary medication, including at least two selfinjectors (I get Twinjects because two injectors have four doses.)  Let the airline know at the time of my reservation of our allergies and that I plan to board early.   Mention this again at the gate.   Bring Clorox wipes and clean my daughter's seat, tray table etc. and the seats on either side or window/wall if she has a window seat.  Bring food so we don't have to rely on the airline food. As mentioned by someone previously, banning peanuts is a slippery slope because there are many people with lifethreatening allergies to many foods. Shellfish allergies are more common in adults than peanuts.Someone wrote above "As for the 'slippery slope' argument  I don't buy it. I've never heard of anyone having a wheat allergy going into anaphylaxis from someone sitting next to them eating a sandwich."Interesting point, but I can turn it around as I have never heard of a documented case of anyone going into anaphylaxis from airborne contact of peanuts. From what I understand, airborne anaphylaxis is very rare.If anything, I would suggest a ban on warming up peanuts, since that is more likely to put peanut proteins in the air. I would also suggest training staff to be sensitive to passengers with allergies.  They should create allergy policies and post them in an easily findable place on their websites (most have them, it's just tough to find on their sites) and be consistent so a passenger doesn't think she is flying on a nutfree flight when it isn't. And while this forum is great, I would weigh more the advice of researchers.  Many people react emotionally regarding this issue and when DOT considers options, it should take into consideration what scientific studies have shown have occurred or may occur, not what wellintentioned people or panicked people think may occur.Epinephrine should always be the responsibility of the passenger, though it may be good policy to have extra on board in the event of an anaphylaxis (or severe asthma attack). A passenger's bill or rights/ responsibilities would be helpful. (e.g. Encourage people with allergies to carry two or more selfinjectors; Giving people with food allergies  Anyone with a medical condition actually  the option to board the plane early.
If you're concerned about wiping down inflight surfaces, I read on the Southwest website that people who are allergic to peanuts can take morning flights, because the planes are cleaned every night.

SofieM(947): If you're concerned about wiping down inflight surfaces, I read on the Southwest website that people who are allergic to peanuts can take morning flights, because the planes are cleaned every night.

Annot: If you're concerned about wiping down inflight surfaces, I read on the Southwest website that people who are allergic to peanuts can take morning flights, because the planes are cleaned every night.
Just as smoking was removed from flights due to the health risks to innocent travelers, this falls into the same category.
angelagarnett(345): Just as smoking was removed from flights due to the health risks to innocent travelers, this falls into the same category.
Annot: Just as smoking was removed from flights due to the health risks to innocent travelers, this falls into the same category.
The main difference is that a peanut reaction happens rather quickly and lung cancer/emphysema can take years.
angelagarnett(345): The main difference is that a peanut reaction happens rather quickly and lung cancer/emphysema can take years.
Annot: The main difference is that a peanut reaction happens rather quickly and lung cancer/emphysema can take years.
This is a very good point
elizwestley(376): This is a very good point
Annot: This is a very good point
and a lot of parallels can be drawn.
elizwestley(376): and a lot of parallels can be drawn.
Annot: and a lot of parallels can be drawn.
There is NO COMPARISON.
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): There is NO COMPARISON.
Annot: There is NO COMPARISON.
Tobacco smoke, unlike peanuts, not only affects EVERYBODY,
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): Tobacco smoke, unlike peanuts, not only affects EVERYBODY,
Annot: Tobacco smoke, unlike peanuts, not only affects EVERYBODY,
it also affects the HVAC and electronics / avionics, onboard an aircraft.
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): it also affects the HVAC and electronics / avionics, onboard an aircraft.
Annot: it also affects the HVAC and electronics / avionics, onboard an aircraft.
Anybody who had done a "C" or "D" check aboard aircraft in the 70's and 80's can tell the difference,
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): Anybody who had done a "C" or "D" check aboard aircraft in the 70's and 80's can tell the difference,
Annot: Anybody who had done a "C" or "D" check aboard aircraft in the 70's and 80's can tell the difference,
especially with the tobacco gunk on the wires and avionics.
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): especially with the tobacco gunk on the wires and avionics.
Annot: especially with the tobacco gunk on the wires and avionics.
Peanuts does not have same health risks "to innocent passengers," as tobacco smoke.
Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): Peanuts does not have same health risks "to innocent passengers," as tobacco smoke.
Annot: Peanuts does not have same health risks "to innocent passengers," as tobacco smoke.
This becomes especially true if there is knowledge and forewarning that the affected passenger assumes that peanuts are going to be served and efforts to mitigate the situation are employed.

Computer_Forensics_Expert(440): This becomes especially true if there is knowledge and forewarning that the affected passenger assumes that peanuts are going to be served and efforts to mitigate the situation are employed.
Annot: This becomes especially true if there is knowledge and forewarning that the affected passenger assumes that peanuts are going to be served and efforts to mitigate the situation are employed.
I don't feel it is a viable solution
elizwestley(376): I don't feel it is a viable solution
Annot: I don't feel it is a viable solution
as a "peanutfree" flight could follow a "peanutallowed" flight on the same plane.
elizwestley(376): as a "peanutfree" flight could follow a "peanutallowed" flight on the same plane.
Annot: as a "peanutfree" flight could follow a "peanutallowed" flight on the same plane.
Leaving peanuts in cushions and peanut residue on everything from the prior flight.
elizwestley(376): Leaving peanuts in cushions and peanut residue on everything from the prior flight.
Annot: Leaving peanuts in cushions and peanut residue on everything from the prior flight.
